habitat_description:
The range of distribution of the banded rock lizard extends from San Gorgonio Pass, Riverside County, California, through the desert region of the Peninsular Ranges as far south as Bahia de los Angeles, Baja California. Its range also includes the upper elevations of the Sierra las Pintas, El Pedregoso in Valle de Gato, Baja California. Isolated populations have been reported on Mejia, Angel de la Guarda, and El Muerto Islands in the Gulf of California (Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003).

This lizard is abundant among boulders in the shady, narrow parts of canyons, and on the slopes of mountains. The habitats of the banded rock lizard include bare rock, talus, scree, cliffs, desert, shrubland, chaparral, and conifer woodland (Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003). In Baja California, populations expand into pinyon/juniper woodlands and chaparral areas of the Sierra San Pedro Martir (Grismer 2002).
